QuestionJSON.Question:
Trinity, a cross country runner, is writing a program to help them keep track of their individual race times in seconds. Trinity wants to write a function to find their fastest (minimum) race time. They have two different algorithms in mind and is unsure about which one to use. Algorithm1 puts all the times into an array and sorts it, then returns the first value. Algorithm2 uses a loop to find the minimum value without sorting. Which algorithm should Trinity use and why?

1// Algorithm1
2class Algorithm1
3
action Main
4
Array<number> raceTimes
5
raceTimes:Add(120)
6
raceTimes:Add(113)
7
raceTimes:Add(109)
8
Sort(raceTimes, 0, raceTimes:GetSize()-1)
9
output raceTimes:At(0)
10
end
11end
12
13// Algorithm2
14class Algorithm2
15
action Main
16
Array<number> raceTimes
17
raceTimes:Add(120)
18
raceTimes:Add(113)
19
raceTimes:Add(109)
20
number minTime = raceTimes:At(0)
21
repeat i = 1 to raceTimes:GetSize() - 1
22
if raceTimes:At(i) < minTime
23
minTime = raceTimes:At(i)
24
end
25
end
26
output minTime
27
end
28end
QuestionJSON.Answer1: Algorithm1 because sorting the array first will make it easier to find the minimum value.
QuestionJSON.Answer2: Algorithm2 because using a loop to find the minimum value without sorting will be faster and more efficient.
QuestionJSON.Answer3: Both algorithms are equally efficient and Trinity can choose either.
QuestionJSON.Answer4: Neither algorithm will work as Trinity needs to use a database to store the race times.
QuestionJSON.Explanation: Algorithm2 is more efficient because it goes through the array of race times only once, so the time complexity is O(n). Algorithm1, on the other hand, needs to sort the array first, which takes more time (O(n log n) for efficient sorting algorithms), then access the first element, which makes it less efficient than Algorithm2.
